description.narrative:
Diakonia har ansökt om finansiering från Sida om SEK 19 035 000 för att utföra rogrammet ”Förstärkt ansvarsutkrävande i Zambia” från 2014 till 2017. Interventionen syftar till att ge rättighetshavare ökad tillgång till resurser genom samarbete med den privata och offentliga sektorn. Programmet har fyra förväntade utfall: (i) att den deltagande privata sektorn agerar på ett transparent sätt, tar ansvar gentemot rättighetshavarna och bidrar till socio-ekonomisk rättvisa i utvalda distrikt i Nord Västra provinsen; (ii), att deltagande lokala statliga myndigheter försäkrar att de offentliga resurserna används på ett transparant och ansvarsfullt sätt och öppnar upp för samhällsdeltagande i planerings- och utvecklingsprocesser; (iii) att internationella institutioner samt nationella och lokala myndigheter försäkrar att det rättsliga regelverket upprätthålls, respekteras och följs av företagssektorn, lokala statliga institutioner och traditionella ledare för transparant och ansvarsfullt utnyttjande av resurser; och (iv) att partnerorganisationerna förbättrar sina interna och externa system och processer för intern demokrati och effektivt genomförande av sina program.
Sida kommer att finansiera hela programmet medan Diakonia kommer att bidra i form av utbildning genom tekniskt stöd från sitt regionala ekonomiska rättighetsprogram i Nairobi.
Diakonia has applied for funding from Sida of SEK19 035 000 to carry out the Strengthened Accountability in Zambia programme from 2014 to 2017.
The intervention aims at empowering right holders to have increased access to resources through engagement with corporate and public sectors.The programme has four expected outcomes: (i) Targeted corporate sector acts in a transparent manner, is accountable to the rights holders and contributing to socio-economic justice in targeted districts of North-Western Province. (ii) Targeted local state authorities ensure that public resources are used in a transparent and accountable way and provide for community participation in planning and development processes (iii) International institutions, National and local authorities ensure that the legal framework is enforced, respected and followed by the corporate sector, local state institutions and traditional leaders for transparent and accountable utilization of resources; and (iv) Partner organizations improve their internal and external systems and processes for internal democracy and effective implementation of their programmes.
Sida will fund the whole programme while Diakonia will contribute in kind towards the training through technical support from its regional economic justice program.
Support to civil society to empower rights holders to engage with Coporate and public sectors for accountability and increased access to resources.
The overall objective of the programme is empowered right holders have increased access to resources through engagement with corporate and public sectors.

description.narrative: The Strengthened Accountability program (SAP) in Zambia is an innovative program that has a perspective beyond aid. It has served as a model governance program which explored how CSOs and communities can work with local authorities and the private sector in natural resource rich rural areas to raise local resources for pro-poor development in a way that takes care of the environment and promotes transparency and accountability. Some of the notable results attained by the program include: -A revenue sharing mechanism campaign early 2016 which led to Solwezi Council passing a resolution to allocate 10% of revenues collected from mining companies to host communities . - Traditional leaders who are the custodians of the land on which most of the mines in North-Western are seating have been supported with information on how to negotiate for better compensation for their people and ensure that they get value for money from the mines in terms of sustainable long term support to their chiefdoms and inclusion of their people in decision making both on the mines Corporate Social Responsibility boards and traditional authority decision making fora. A negotiation handbook for traditional leaders was developed, printed and translated. Traditional Leaders like Chief Mumena of the Kaonde people of North Western province are now taking an active role in the dialogues and welfare promotion of his community. - As a result of the advocacy, an Agreement between the Council and FQM Kanshanshi Mine set aside some revenues for rehabilitation of township roads in Solowezi at the North-Western provincial indaba held in 2017. This is a cost sharing agreement where the Council contributes as well as the mine, a number of roads in Solowezi town have been tarred. - Women’s economic empowerment in Solowezi resulting in one of the women’s groups being registered as a supplier to the mines. -There is now evidence of increased visibility of the provincial authority and the municipal council at community level meetings/forums to listen to the concerns of the people and take action. For example, in Chavuma, the council involved some residents in the budgeting and prioritization of issues for the district’s long-term district strategy. -The evaluation also found that the people in the target areas have increased their knowledge on human right and are now able to participate meaningfully in their local governance. -Partners' capacities were built in various fields such as project design, planning and management, and financial management for all the 5 partners. 3 out of the 5 partners; EITA, FODEP and YAD were supported in developing strategic plans and M&E systems. -One of the unexpected results from this program was that the implementing civil society partners became mediators between mining companies and communities over compensation disagreements. This has helped the displaced people to have a voice and the mines also values the CSOs because they could not negotiate on their own as communities had become hostile and could not trust them.
